en: Interview with Christian David Rivera, 2021-02-03

Interview with Christian David Rivera, member of the Rising from the Ashes team, conducted by Casey Kaufman. Rivera shares his family experiences of the wildfires, including his father who was unable to leave work for three days following the fires. He also discusses the difficulties faced by the Latinx community in Gatlinburg following the wildfires. This is a representative quote from the interview: "The Hispanic community in particular was not just freely going out and asking for help, unless it was given to them. But eventually, I think the community realized what was happening, and so I did notice on social media, such as Facebook, there would be a few places that were giving out help, sending out messages saying, you know, come get help. We're not gonna ask for I.D. or documentation or any of that."

Interview Questions
Can you state your name and tell us a bit about yourself?
What are you majoring in at UTK?
Can you tell us about your experiences in the summer and fall leading up to the 2016 wildfires?
Were you at home with your parents at the time?
Can you tell us where in the Gatlinburg area you were living at the time?
Can you walk us through your experiences on the Monday leading into the evening?
So your father had to stay at work for 3 days without being able to leave?
Your father had to stay because the city wasn't letting additional people leave?
What was it like when you were able to finally reconnect as a family?
Did you hear any other stories from people that were trapped in the city and unable to get out?
What was your return to Gatlinburg like? When were you able to return?
Do you recall any specific interactions with people at Rocky Top?
Do you know people that decided to leave after the wildfires, or just never came back?
Was there any support for people in rebuilding their lives?
Was there a point where you were able to reconnect with friends or others in the community?
Earlier you mentioned your sibling, where they still in school, or what was it like for them returning to school?
Talking about the Latinx community and how that are of Gatlinburg wasn't rebuilt, how would you describe the reconstruction efforts in general?
Do you remember any specific groups that offered aid without requiring documentation?
How did the fires shape community relations?
Did you hear the rumor that the official death count was not accurate?
Has your father's health recovered?

We've spoken with researchers concerning climate change causing more fires in the future, do you feel like people in the community are aware that climate change exacerbated the conditions leading to the 2016 wildfires?
As a young person who lived through this event, how would you say this event affected your life, the trajectory of it, or emotionally?
As a young person who lived through this event, how would you say this event affected your life, the trajectory of it, or emotionally?
Is there anything that we haven't covered that you would like to discuss?
